Hi All!

I first played DOMO back in 2008 with Aeria and I am really glad Suba gave it an other chance.

I like how the game gives you to choice to solo or party up and keeps both paths viable. The class system is nothing I have ever seen before or since. You can level up all 14 classes on the same character (classes open up at lvl 10), and you can mix and match their skills. You can sub 2 skill groups from other jobs to our current one.

The maps are decent sized but with flying available from lvl 15 and teleports to all cities getting around is easy. For the lazier or richer folks there are the item mall Teleport to Parties or Go Anywheres. If you are bored of murdering creeps hourly events can keep you entertained (quiz show/treasure hunt/pupu darts/flying race etc.) for quite some time.

Pets are an other highlight of the game. Other than they help you fight with each having their strength and weaknesses once you level and evolve them to lvl 61 they can become mounts (both riding and flying). Riding a huge metal bear or flying on a winged cat (my personal favourite) are both great. Or if you so prefer get one of the cute/handsome humanoid pets. ;)

It is true there are technical issues and things the game can improve on. However several of the negatives have a sollution ready if people were willing to look around.
- WASD is available from options
- Screen resolution can be fixed in the game files
- The font the game uses can be downloaded to fix the text issue lot of people has
- Start village is instanced, that is why you do not see anyone, the game is not a ghost town
- While only a few hair colours are available from the character creation you can buy a lot more later from the Item Mall or other players.

Item mall is just what you would expect from a free to play game. XP and loot boosters, luxury items and of course countless cosmetics.

As for end game there are several guild based raids with billboards to show off your times (while pocketing loot) and compete with other guilds. If you are the bloodthirsty kind you can also hop in the Arena for some PvP action (also with billboard). Or, if you are one of the clumsy you can try climbing the death billboard. :)

There are no perfect or bugless games. But if you really want to give DOMO a try there is a way to run it without most of the issues mentioned in reviews. Please keep in mind the game is old, and due to that it cannot race with modern games in a lot of aspects. Should you like it the main concern would be how long the developer (SoftStar) will support such an old game.

If you want some nostalgy, or want to have something to pass time with give it a try.

Name any other game where your cup size is a game mechanic. 10/10

Also there is WASD controls avaliable if needed.  Just need to toggle em in the settings, but this locks out the click movement.  So sadly, its one or the other.   Not both at the same time.

I have a little bias for this game due to dumping time into the AeriaGames version in the past.

...Hi all...
Okay, so i see a lot of negative reviews for this game.  This actually makes me a little upset, as to this day, this game remains one of my favorite mmos.  I understand its not perfect, and I also understand a lot of the launch problems are partially due to crappy default options.  I'll go over how to fix the main issues i found first.  Honestly, I feel like Suba dropped the ball a little bit, but hopefully, it wont ruin the experience that much if you know how to handle it.
One of the main complaints that I see, and actually came across myself, was the screen going below the start bar.  This makes it so you can't access the options panel to fix said screen resolution.  A real problem.  To fix this, press Ctrl+n in game to bring up the options menu and change the resolution from there.  My personal favorite is Windows-Full screen, which resizes the window to exact area of your screen minus the start bar. Feel free to pick whatever works for you.
Let's fix another complaint I see a lot: lack of sound.  This game has a beautiful soundtrack (obviously my opinion, but still).  However, for some reason, the music defaults to muted.  You can go ahead and fix that in the sound options while you have the menu open.  No big deal.
Other random stuff I want to address: The character creation in this game IS good...if you look at it a certain way.  There are four races and genders, and while they are all basically 'humanoid', they're fine as they are really.  When I hear people talk about lack of customization options in this game, I think they must be talking about face and hair styles, for which each race and gender has only 5.  However, this is the only game I've played that gave full character proportion control to the player.  Not only that, but the Eversun Elder quests make these decisions early on important.  In the end, you're left with what can only be described as 'your character'...and really, that's exactly what it's supposed to do.  It's not as great as it could be, but I've seen much, much worse...
Now that Sound and Image are fixed, lets continue down to controls.  This is where you can turn on ASWD if that is you prefered gaming style.  This will deactivate your chatbox, and make it so you can use the keyboard to move.  For the record, even if you have ASWD off, the arrow keys on the keyboard will move your character just fine. Anyway, fine tune the rest of the options as you want.  After all, the key is for you to enjoy it.
Now on to the review proper.  I'll start by saying, DoMO is one of those games that requires team work and patience from the get go.  And I don't just mean in repetative questing (but, yeah, that too). One monster in the well that is required for a title spawns once every 45 minutes to an hour.  The best option is to team up so everyone gets the title...and wait for it to spawn...and wait...and wait... Grinding is a staple in mmos, and its in full force here.  There is no real easy way to get experience as a soloer past a certain point.
Waiting might sound like a pain, but in a way, its brilliant.  When your forced to wait collectively in a group for long stretches of time, inevitably, bonds will be formed.  I have met so many people through this game over the last 3 years, and the strongest bonds I have are with my guild mates, who kept me company over time that i otherwise would have been fiddling my fingers... My point here is, join a guild.  Any guild is fine.  A good, active guild, even if they aren't in a team with you, will keep you entertained even when the game itself slows down.
What's that? Sounds like a lot of time you don't have? That's fine.  Even a casual player can find value in game as an alchemist.  The crafting in this game, while not always making sense (The only thing that is used to make a wooden sheild...is glass...) is pretty easy to figure out.  Weapons and armor are made using monster drops and Collection items.  Collection includes Mining, Meditation, Fishing, etc. and can easily be done while your away doing your business (I'm collecting iron bars myself right now actually).  When collection is done, you can use your items for crafting, or sell you finds to other players.
Oh, and there are currently 13 classes in game...should prolly mention that.  You start the game as a commoner, and have to make it to lvl 10 before you can earn any of the other ones.  During this time, you'll learn no attack skills, but just getting thru the tutorial area should get you somewhere between 6-8 easily.  Completing the Eversun Guide missions when you reach the city should easily get you high enough for your first job.  There are 3 rows of hot keys for a reason.  While you have a main job equiped, you can substitute jobs from other classes to help you out.  I recommend learning doctor skills early, so you can sub a healing spell for whenever you need it.  Not all skill work the same on every class, and many skill require certain weapons that your main job may not be able to equip by default.  However, with enough grinding, technically you can use any skill on any job to some degree.  Finding your favorite class and sub combination can be a game all in itself.
I feel like I've devolved into ranting... so final thoughts:  This game is NOT perfect.  If you want proof, ask anyone in game about the stairs... However, for what it is, DoMO is an enjoyable experience, especially if you choose to take part in the community.  I may be disappointed in the Suba launch on Steam, but I still recommend people at least try this game.  It might not have the flashiest graphics, or the fastest action, or extreme whatever, but in terms of a nice, slow way to enjoy a day, this is one of my favorite options.

-Timreh

reviewText:
Lemme get this out of the way first.  Even though Steam says I've only played this game for half an hour, it doesn't account for all the time I spent on it when the game was new, nearly ten years ago.  I have some pretty fond memories of playing it with my friends, but it was in the barrage of all the different MMOs we tried together and we didn't really tend to stick with any of them all that terribly long.

A lot of the MMORPGs from that time played similarly and bled together to the point you really couldn't tell that much of them apart, and while DOMO was no exception to that, I liked it for its unique job system.  You can change jobs at any time in the game, level up that particular job enough to learn skillsets from that job permenantly and use them with other jobs.  Essentially, it's a game where you hybridize your job classes, much like Final Fantasy V.

That being said, there's really not much else that sets this game apart from other MMORPGs, and it suffers for that now as much as it did then.  So it's not just that it's dated (though it most certainly is), it was just never that interesting to begin with.  The job system was great, the game itself just wasn't strong enough to support it.  For a while, the North American server cancelled the game and it could only be played in Europe and other regions, so it's frankly kinda surprising to me to see it on Steam all these years later.

Would I recommend it?  Sure, but it's not for everyone, and it probably won't appeal to many people anymore.  But it does have flirty zombies.  That alone might make the game worth playing for, at least for a little while.

As a veteran of another MMO, Mabinogi, having played for almost 7 years, that didn't happen there in my newbie days. At all. This game is rather aged, a diamond from the past in a sense, however, but if you think about it, it was almost ahead of it's time back then. The graphics are decent given it's age.

There's also the option to make a secondary class as well, which means, let's say you want to be a doctor but also a dancer. Pros:
- Decent graphics and animations for it's age
- Friendly community
- 15 classes to choose from without being bound to any of them
- Decently large maps
- Faster traveling with flying"
- Pet system/Taming system

Cons:
- Clunky UI
- Some bugs and crashing
- No option to turn the "Red thread of Fate" effects off
- Quirky flying controls

Alright so I'm gonna list some pros and cons, some of them more of a personal opinion here.
Pros: It has a lot of nostalgia to it, probably because I played the game years ago when it was under Aeria. The art style makes up for what it lacks in graphics. The game is colorful, but doesn't give you a headache. The game is also unique in that you can become qualified for all classes, and switch whenever you want. The music is also rather unique, and I love it.
Cons: The text is VERY small, however, this can be fixed by downloading a font called Mingliu, which can be downloaded safely and for free from FontPalace, as I did. (Edit: The font is specifically called Mingliu Regular). The game is prone to crashing often and every time you tab out. There is no quest tracker in the UI (but you do have a journal to keep track of current quests). There is no solo auto-loot. It's easy to get caught on the terrain, especially stairs and curbs. Sometimes monsters walk through the walls, though this poses no problem in hitting them and dragging them back out. reviewText:
I played this back in '11, so I was late to the party, but I can safely say it's among my favorite MMOs.

If you don't have friends to play with and aren't looking to socialize with this game's playerbase, then this game isn't for you -- solo play becomes a grindy, arduous chore and all but the most dedicated MMO players will grow bored before hitting Lv. 20, and oftentimes the sluggish feeling is only mitigated by purchases from the currently-lackluster Item Mall.

If you're a socialite and tend to stick around to play with friends and meet new ones, then you'll be all over this game for sure. Partying up for a good grind is much more enjoyable -- relaxing between punching sessions nets some fun conversations and memorable moments, and joining a guild makes for the opportunity to establish real connections with some of these people. While the in-game social structure isn't used quite as much as it was intended (to my knowledge), it certainly lives up to its promise of emphasis on social interaction.

reviewText:
Before I start my review, I just want to mention that I would recommend downloading from subagames.com instead of steam. I'll explain why in a bit.
I remember spending hours on this game back when it was run by Aeria Games, so I was pretty excited to see its return. It's fairly simple to figure out if you pay attention to any tutorials that you encounter as you progress.
Character customization is very limited if you don't want to spend any money, but there are a lot of costumes, hair dye, etc that you can get either for real money through the item shop or if you manage to save up enough in-game currency to buy from other players.
One of this games winning features is the variety in careers you can choose after completing simple qualification quests.  There are 13 careers, each with a unique skill set. At any time, you can switch between careers and level them up individually. You can also add a sub-career which allows you to combine skills from two different professions.
Like most mmorpg, this game can get a little bit grindy.  Of course, leveling up goes much quicker in a team.  What some players do for resource collection is open a second account. It is possible to have two games running on one computer and switch between them if you download it from the suba games website.  It works best if you set the graphics to full window.  Then you can have one collecting resources while you do quests with the other, and you can trade between them.
Personally, this is probably my favorite free mmorpg to play at this point.  It is not too complicated, and it has plenty of variety to keep you occupied for many hours.  I would definitely recommend trying it. Just make sure you give it at least an hour before you decide what you think.

Okay, first and formost: you need to link a SubaGames account to your steam acount in order to play through steam. This  process is done through Steam Overlay and the process will fail if you have it turned off.

Next: Ctrl+n will bring up the options menu, even on the title screen. From there you can enable AWSD for movement and change your visual settings.

The game has 4 races and something like 13 job classes. You can switch between classes freely after you unlock each one.

Combat if simple: click your target to auto attack and use skills through their assigned hotkeys.

Colors are bright, character models are simple and look Anime-ish.

Somewhat grindy but not too steep and the begining. Lots of quests if that's your thing, and some social mechanics like Mentor/Student bonuses and in-game marriage.

Yes, I recoment trying this game. Its not like you'll be out any money just for giving it a shot.

reviewText:
Before I start my review, I just want to mention that I would recommend downloading from subagames.com instead of steam. I'll explain why in a bit.
I remember spending hours on this game back when it was run by Aeria Games, so I was pretty excited to see its return. It's fairly simple to figure out if you pay attention to any tutorials that you encounter as you progress.
Character customization is very limited if you don't want to spend any money, but there are a lot of costumes, hair dye, etc that you can get either for real money through the item shop or if you manage to save up enough in-game currency to buy from other players.
One of this games winning features is the variety in careers you can choose after completing simple qualification quests.  There are 13 careers, each with a unique skill set. At any time, you can switch between careers and level them up individually. You can also add a sub-career which allows you to combine skills from two different professions.
Like most mmorpg, this game can get a little bit grindy.  Of course, leveling up goes much quicker in a team.  What some players do for resource collection is open a second account. It is possible to have two games running on one computer and switch between them if you download it from the suba games website.  It works best if you set the graphics to full window.  Then you can have one collecting resources while you do quests with the other, and you can trade between them.
Personally, this is probably my favorite free mmorpg to play at this point.  It is not too complicated, and it has plenty of variety to keep you occupied for many hours.  I would definitely recommend trying it. Just make sure you give it at least an hour before you decide what you think.
